{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3356902,"name":"Carter Ryba","username":"10219Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-09T21:55:50.581Z","cooked":"

I’m trying to create a custom path using PathPlanner because I heard it’s good, however, I cannot figure out anything to do with the PathPlanner gui. I’m trying to make it where it starts from a driver station and then stops at the speaker, shoots a note, and then backs up, is there a way to set rotation and stuff whenever you aren’t using holonomic mode? I’m not seeing anything, and whenever I try to set a wait command it just doesn’t wait or anything.

Field2560×1439 189 KB

Settings791×416 10.8 KB

I think what you’re trying to do can’t be done with event markers. Those are better to run commands while you’re moving along a path. But honestly, I haven’t tried running them like that, so I could be wrong. If you want to stop driving and run commands, you need to add them to an auto group.

First, start by splitting up the auto into a couple paths

one for this

image404×552 16 KB

and the other for this

image459×610 22.2 KB

Then you can string the follow path commands together in an auto along with your shooting commands. Make sure you register the named commands.

image1582×887 81.2 KB

(my bad for not matching up the start and end points for the auto, you should use linked waypoints for this)

Hopefully, this is what you’re looking for. If you have any questions, feel free to reach out!

yeah sure no problem!

Can I get the link to your code if it’s public and I can show you how to add those commands?

To use your gyro to turn to the right angle, you need to use a PID controller to basically control how much your robot needs to turn. The first thing I’d do before you try to program this is make sure your NavX works and log the angles coming from it.

Here’s my team’s code from last year (apologies that its kind of disorganized but it would be great if any other teams could share their code snippets.) Then you want to log the outputs from your gyro with SmartDashboard.putNumber("GyroAngle", gyro.getYawAngle()) and see if it updates correctly in shuffleboard.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2024-04-09T22:47:52.585Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":83,"readers_count":82,"score":56.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":461997,"topic_slug":"differential-drive-path-planner","display_username":"Carter Ryba","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65624,"username":"10219Ryba","name":"Carter Ryba","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/10219ryba/{size}/248339_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":65624,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"9764, 10219"},"post_url":"/t/differential-drive-path-planner/461997/6","custom_user_title":"9764, 10219","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3358605,"name":"NewtonCrosby","username":"NewtonCrosby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-11T12:36:15.909Z","cooked":"

We successfully used Path Planner with differential drive this year for our robot. That code base is in Python, but it will hopefully give you some reference point. It is a drivetrain that uses CTRE motor controllers, and simulation is fully supported. So without a robot, you can simulate our code and play around with it.

Some notes:

  1. We didn’t use event markers, for things that you would use event markers for (say triggering the intake at a certain point) we just built auto sequences around singular paths, rather than one really complex path with markers.
  2. Your robot commands need to account for Field Oriented driving, with an Always Blue Origin.
  3. Your robot needs to have a gyro that reports Counter Clockwise Positive CCW+. For example, we use a Navx which is CW+, so we need to properly adjust the gyro heading to make it CCW+.
  4. Your code needs to maintain accurate odometry (meaning, when your robot drives 1 meter in a direction, your robot knows that it has driven 1 meter in that direction)
  5. Your code needs to have a reliable way to drive with feedforward and PID correction when driving your paths.
  6. The LTV controller is way easier to tune than the Ramsete.

By following those steps we were able to reliably draw paths and deploy them in our events without worrying about the consequences since we knew the robot would follow the paths reliably.

I assume you’re using the kitbot so you can take a look at this for the code for that (it doesn’t have path planner though)

FIRST – 10 Aug 23

KitBot

*/

This uses a logging framework called Advantage Kit which allows you review your log files after running the robot. The code looks a little different from normal, but you can look at the Subsystem.java files (for example Drive.java and Launcher.java) and the auto builder implementation.

I tried to code it however, I wasn’t able to get the robot to go to a specified angle even though it says the go to 90 it would just go back and forth and not stop, I did essentially try to copy some code off an example, and my gyro is displaying output, but its either not accurate enough or something else is going on.

if it’s oscillating like that, you need to tune PID. If it’s oscillating near the 90-degree setpoint, then it means your gyro is correct.

Take a look at these instructions for tuning
https://docs.wpilib.org/en/2020/docs/software/advanced-control/introduction/tuning-pid-controller.html
